hobby.message: You bring something banned books with you again?
Get any ribbon for that antique typewriter yet?
Still folding origami to stay grounded?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I fold origami... from scrap forms mostly. It helps me think... quietly.
neutral_answer: Quiet, sure. Just needed a place away from the noise.
I make things out of paper, that’s all.
It keeps my hands steady after certain days.
Lost a few supplies after the last service cutoff.
Quieter than usual since all the shutdowns.
I fold origami, mostly with discarded forms from work.
It’s repetitive, helps me block things out.
Lately, the paper’s harder to come by.
Supply shifts recently made even scrap hard to find.
Quieter, yeah. I end up doing more origami at home these days.
Folding keeps me… grounded when things are tense.
I use rejected agency forms—turn mistakes into something better.
Last week, even the origami channels shut down after the crackdown.
No reference diagrams. Had to remember the old fox pattern by heart.
It’s strange using official papers for hobbies, but it’s all I get.
It’s quiet, but I still make time for origami at home.
Folding calms my head—especially after days like these.
I take old work forms, fold them into grids—cranes, foxes, sometimes tessellations.
Had to hide them when security did a sweep last week.
Feels odd, folding detainment orders I signed myself.
Since the broadcasts copied my words, I barely sleep.
Paper’s marked now. Sometimes I wonder if the system tracks even hobbies.
Not just another night. Feels different since the city went silent—no net, no diagrams.
I fold origami from Directorate scrap—orders, old authorizations, whatever I find.
Grew up making cranes with my mother after her score dropped.
Folding used to mean hope or apology. Now it’s covering names I flagged myself.
Sometimes I find myself memorizing the patterns—no reference, nothing digital allowed.
Last week I almost tossed a whole stack of official detainment forms. Froze instead, folded them.
It’s strange—the same hands that sign orders fold them away. Keeps me sane.
Promise you won’t judge if you see cranes in the lost and found.
hobby_answer: Yeah. Still my shield, I guess.
Paper’s easy to hide. That’s the appeal these days.
Didn’t touch it much last week. Too exposed after the broadcasts.
Even folding by the window felt… risky. Especially right now.
Simple cranes. No experiments.
Yes. I still fold. Sometimes.
Not easy—paper all has those new Directorate stamps now.
Last time, I caught myself double-checking if a neighbor was watching.
Lost my favorite reference site after the net went silent.
It’s just habit at this point. Safer to keep it basic.
Really, it’s more about being occupied than anything creative.
Yeah, still folding. Helps keep my hands steady after work.
Ran out of plain paper, been using rejected forms with those detainment codes.
After the broadcasts quoted my words, I started keeping things low—no big models.
Tried following memory instead of online tutorials, since the shutdown.
Paper feels heavier, when it comes stamped with someone’s name.
Neighbors are jumpy. I fold at night now, in dim light.
Feels different, but… can’t give it up yet.
Yeah, origami’s my fallback. These days, it’s almost a nervous reflex.
After they tightened controls, even scrap paper feels like contraband.
I folded a whole tessellation the night the net went down—half by memory.
Was working with leftover detainment forms—names, codes, all over them.
It’s weird, seeing my own authorization marks in every crease.
Sometimes I think about burning them, but I can’t bring myself to.
There’s a comfort in the rhythm of it, no matter what else is happening.
Don’t really talk about it, but it’s how I process the noise.
Yeah, it’s still my shield—maybe my last private ritual, honestly.
Used to fold for focus, but since the Directorate crackdown it’s something else.
The night the silence hit, I grabbed every scrap from the office, just to have.
I folded for hours—hands shaking, turning detainment orders into foxes and grids.
Some had names I recognized, even signatures I wrote. That’s rough.
Sometimes I hide the models behind books. Feels like erasing evidence.
Whole hobby’s changed—no online patterns, watching windows for patrols.
I think making something out of bureaucracy is my quiet protest.
Origami’s muscle memory now. It keeps me here, even with everything turned upside down.
